revision.text:
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Mzoudi.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Mzoudi, smiling after acquittal]] --> '''Abdelghani Mzoudi''' ({{IPAc-en|audio=En-us-Abdelghani Mzoudi from Morocco pronunciation (Voice of America).ogg|ɑː|b|d|ɛ|l|'|g|ɑː|n|iː|_|m|'|z|aʊ|d|iː}}; {{lang-ar|عبد الغني مزودي}}; born December 6, 1972, in [[Marrakech]], [[Morocco]]), also transliterated as '''Abdul Ghani Mzoudi''', was an alleged member of [[al-Qaeda]] and an associate of [[Mohamed Atta]], the ringleader of the [[September 11 attacks]] who also served as the hijacker-pilot of [[American Airlines Flight 11]].
==Life== In 1999, Mzoudi lived in the [[Hamburg cell]], an apartment owned by Atta, where many of the [[Hijackers in the September 11 attacks|organizers of the September 11 attacks]] met and planned their future. His specific role in the attacks has not been determined, but he does not seem to have attempted to enter the United States at any time.
Mzoudi was captured and tried in Germany, along with [[Mounir el-Motassadeq]], on charges relating to the [[9/11 attacks]]. In their trials, both claimed [[Ramzi bin al-Shibh]], a key planner of the attacks, would have given statements indicating their innocence. Both asked for the United States to present bin al-Shibh as a witness, and the judge agreed that this was a reasonable request. Although the German Justice Ministry pressed the U.S. to present bin al-Shibh, the United States refused, and Mzoudi was thereby acquitted in February 2004. Some observers believe that he would have been convicted had bin al-Shibh been made available as a witness. [[Ziad Jarrah]]'s fiancee Aysel Sengün testified at Mzoudi's trial.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070529125318/http://iafrica.com/news/worldnews/263057.htm]
In June 2005, a German federal appeals court upheld the acquittal due to insufficient evidence for retrial. The [[German Interior Ministry]] was seeking to deport Mzoudi, though the defense team was considering asking for asylum.
Mzoudi was finally deported to [[Morocco]] where he now lives as a free man.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100807204647/http://www.gpoaccess.gov/911/index.html The Final 9/11 Commission Report] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040401233653/http://www.unknownnews.net/040206secretjustice.html Mzoudi's acquittal] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4076346.stm Acquittal of 9/11 suspect upheld], [[BBC]], 9 June 2005
{{GermanTerrorism}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mzoudi, Abdelghani}} [[Category:Moroccan people]] [[Category:People from Marrakesh]] [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:September 11 attacks]] [[Category:Hamburg cell]]
{{Morocco-paramilitary-bio-stub}}

'''Ambrose D. Richard''' (February 6, 1850 – 1917) was a lawyer and political figure of [[Acadian]] descent in [[New Brunswick]], Canada. He represented [[Westmorland County, New Brunswick|Westmorland County]] in the [[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick]] from 1895 to 1899 as a [[Conservative Party of New Brunswick|Conservative]] member.
He was born in [[Memramcook, New Brunswick]], the son of David Richard and Julie Ouelette. Richard was educated at [[University of St. Joseph's College|St. Joseph's College]] there, at [[Saint Dunstan's University|St. Dunstan's College]] in [[Prince Edward Island]] and at [[Boston University]]. He was called to the bar in 1879. In 1884, he married Lizzie V. Holt. Richard served on the municipal council for [[Dorchester, New Brunswick|Dorchester]] and was a commissioner for Westmorland County. He was a member of the [[Legislative Council of New Brunswick|Legislative Council]] from 1882 to 1891. He ran unsuccessfully for a seat in the provincial assembly in 1892 after being named solicitor general.
== References == *[http://www.canadiana.org/ECO/mtq?doc=32962 ''The Canadian parliamentary companion, 1897'' JA Gemmill]

{{NewBrunswick-politician-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Orphan|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox first lady | name = Ammar Abo Bakr | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1980|2|14}} | birth_name = Ammar Abo Bakr | residence = [[Luxor, Egypt]] | alma_mater = [[Luxor University]] | profession = Artist and professor |known_for = [[Mohamed Mahmoud graffiti]], [[street art]], [[graffiti]] }} '''Ammar Abo Bakr''' is a well-known muralist and graffiti artist in Egypt. His work depicts the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]], portraits, Egyptian history, and Egyptian pop culture. Throughout the revolution, Ammar Abo Bakr painted amidst resistance from the police force, which would cover his art with white paint as a sign of criminal justice.{{cite web|accessdate=April 28, 2015 |url=https://www.motherjones.com/mixed-media/2014/01/jehane-noujaim-the-square-egypt-oscars-ammar-abo-bakr-karim-amer |title= How the Artists of "The Square" Fueled Egypt's Revolution |author= Maddie Oatman}} His work often challenges government regimes or injustices and is most famously found on [[Mohamed Mahmoud Street]]. However, it can also be seen in other places in Cairo, Alexandria, Beirut, Brussels, Amsterdam, Berlin, Cologne and Frankfurt.[http://www.re-aligned.net/ammar-abo-bakr/?lang=en Ammar Abo Bakr]. ''Aligned'', Accessed on April 28, 2015. In an interview with Sarah Mousa of [[Jadaliyya]], Abo Bakr said, "...While we [artists] strongly oppose the military and want to mark that stance, we love the people and would also like to present art to the people... I want to present something of beauty to people who can see it, see that their streets have beautiful murals and feel joy. Abo Bakr currently also works with other artists on murmurous projects within and outside Egypt. "{{cite web|date=January 27, 2014|work=[[Jadaliyya]]|accessdate=April 30, 2015 |url= http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/16192/ammar-abo-bakr_committing-murder-then-marching-in- |title=Ammar Abo Bakr: Committing Murder, then Marching in the Funeral Procession|author= Sarah Mousa}} ==Biography== Ammar Abo Bakr is a mural artist from Egypt. His works have cased walls in Cairo, Luxor, Alexandria, Beirut, Frankfurt, Berlin, Amsterdam and Brussels.[http://www.tea-after-twelve.com/about-us/authors/ammar-abo-bakr/#sthash.Ovycn9GW.dpuf Ammar Abo Bakr]. ''Tea After Twelve'', issue #03. Ammar Abo Bakr was born on February 14, 1980.[https://www.facebook.com/Ammar.Abo.Bakr/timeline Facebook, Ammar Abo Bakr]. Accessed on April 28, 2015. He attended [[Luxor Institute of Fine Arts]] from 1996 and 2001 where he ''studied painting''. Beginning in 2004, Abo Bakr began researching the Egyptian people, looking for inspiration for his artwork. In addition to creating his own [[graffiti]] pieces, he was a professor at the Luxor Institute of Fine Arts where he attended school. === His Work=== Ammar's work depicts the [[history of Egypt]], [[Islamic culture]], and the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]]. Some of his most well known murals were on Mohamed Mahmoud Street which is close to [[Tahrir Square]] where the January 25 revolution occurred. His work is inspired by what is going on in the country at the time and by what society wants.
Since his work often goes against the government, it can be dangerous when creating these works or murals. He sometimes has to take time off in a certain location because he knows of many family and friends who have gone to prison. During and shortly after the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]], ''Ammar'' was busy putting graffiti on anything he could find. Other artists and activists were also writing on public spaces, so not only were they sending messages to the government, but they also were keeping up a dialogue among themselves and responding to other artists' graffiti work. His work on Mohamed Mahmoud Street was especially important because this street connects Tahrir Square and the Ministry of the Interior. The graffiti on this street served as a "newspaper" of what was happening during the revolution. When writing about his work, Abo Bakr noted, "What we did in Egypt in recent years was not about presenting art, at least it wasn't to me: We used walls as a newspaper... Me, I was a fine arts assistant professor. I left the faculty of arts to report on the revolution in the city’s walls."{{cite web|accessdate=April 28, 2015 |url=http://www.tea-after-twelve.com/all-issues/issue-01/issue-01-overview/chapter2/art-revolution/ |title= Tea After Twelve ch.2 |author= Ammar Abo Bakr}} In 2012, Ammar, along with other artists started the "No Walls" campaign. This campaign was aiming to cover with graffiti all of the concrete barricades that had been put up by the government.[http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/cairos-graffiti-revolution/ Cairo's graffiti revolution]. ''CBS News'', Accessed on April 28, 2015. The government put barricades up in neighborhoods, which were not only a visual sign of oppression but also inconvenienced the community members because they had to navigate through the barricades. Along with famous artists, many community members helped paint the walls. There were intricate murals or simple paintings of the continuation of the street behind the barricades. The goal of the campaign was to use [[trompe l’oeil]] to artistically transform the restrictive barriers put in place by Egypt's Interior Ministry, in order to make it appear as if they were not there.{{cite journal |last= Abaza |first= Mona |date= October 9, 2012|title= Walls, Segregating Downtown Cairo and the Mohammed Mahmud Street Graffiti |doi= 10.1177/0263276412460062 |journal= Theory, Culture & Society|publisher= SAGE |pages= 1–18 }} Ammar is strongly connected with everyday Egyptian people. He credits them for giving him his inspiration and creativity.[http://www.slow-words.com/ammar-abo-bakr-graffiti-artist/ Ammar Abo Bakr, graffiti artist]. ''Slow Words'', Accessed on April 28, 2015. He also believes that the art in [[Luxor]] and [[Cairo]] should remain out of galleries because that limits who sees it and because art is constantly changing. ==See also== * [[Tahrir Square]] * [[Cairo]] * [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] * [[Arab Spring]] * [[Graffiti]] * [[Contemporary art in Egypt]] == References == {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bakr, Ammar Abo}} [[Category:People of the Egyptian revolution of 2011]] [[Category:Graffiti and unauthorised signage]] [[Category:Egyptian artists]] [[Category:1980 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{unreliable sources|date=October 2016}}
{{Use Indian English|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Hindu leader | image = Jillellamudi Amma, Mother of All(Viswajanani).jpg | name = Anasuya Devi | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date |df=yes|1923|3|28}} | birth_place = Mannava, [[Mannava]] Panchayat, [[Guntur]] District, (now [[Andhra Pradesh]]), [[India]] | birth_name = Anasuya |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1985|6|12|1923|3|28}} |death_place = [[Jillellamudi]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[India]] | guru = | philosophy = | honors = | literary_works = | footnotes= }} {{quote box|width=22em|title=Quotation|quote="Mother exists forever and includes everything within herself. She who is everything and everywhere is Mother. It is not correct to say Mother of the Universe. The Universe itself is the Mother"<ref name="Reference1">"The Path of the Mother By Savitri L. Bess", {{ISBN|0-345-42347-X}}, p.68</ref>}} '''Matrusri Anasuya Devi''' (born 28 March 1923 – 1985), better known simply as '''Amma''' ["Mother"], was an Indian spiritual [[guru]] from [[Andhra Pradesh]].
==Early life== Anasuya Devi was an Indian guru from Jillellamudi (now partially known as [[Arkapuri]]), [[Guntur District]], in the state of [[Andhra Pradesh]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Conway, Timothy|title=Women of Power & Grace: Nine Astonishing, Inspiring Luminaries of Our Time|publisher= Wake Up Pr (April 1996)|place= New York|year= 1996}}</ref> to a couple late Seethapathi Rao, the village officer of Mannava and his wife Rangamma. Seethapathi and Rangamma after their loss of as many as five children. Rangamma conceived a child, said to be a [[Miraculous birth|miraculous conception]],<ref name="ReferenceB">"50 Spiritual Appetizers: Principles of Good Governance By Vinod Dhawan", {{ISBN|978-1-4828-3471-0}}, p.43</ref> and gave birth to Anasuya, born with a vermilion on her forehead per the account of biographer Richard Schiffman.<ref name="ReferenceA">''Mother of All: A Revelation of the Motherwood of God in the Life and Teachings of the Mother'', {{ISBN|8178221144}}, Section 20</ref><ref name="birth">Bollée, Willem. "Physical Aspects of Some Mahāpuruṣas Descent, Foetality, Birth." Wiener Zeitschrift für Die Kunde Südasiens / Vienna Journal of South Asian Studies, vol. 49, 2005, pp. 5–34.p9 https://www.jstor.org/stable/24007652.</ref>
When Anasuya was completing her second year, she once sat under a pomegranate tree in "[[Lotus position|padmasana]]" (Lotus Posture) and attained a [[transcendental meditation]] state, with her eyes half closed. Every one mistook it as a fit of [[epilepsy]] and not noticing the '[[yogasana]]' she had assumed. She returned to her normal consciousness in an hour. On yet another occasion, she was seen sitting in a strange posture with her breath suspended and the eyes turned completely inside. When someone asked her later as to what she was doing, she replied she was in '[[List of mudras (yoga)|Shambhavi Mudra]]'.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}`
As a little girl, she never asked for food, just as she never cried for milk as an infant. She accepted food if it was given, only to give to somebody else who was in need of it. She was treated by several doctors to no avail. It is a [[paradox]] of Amma's life that one who was indifferent to eating herself, spent a large portion of her time and energy in feeding others.<ref name="ReferenceE">"[http://indiantempleslist.blogspot.com/2015/03/jillellamudi-amma-temple-near-bapatla.html]", 17 February 2012, Annapurnalayam</ref>
On 5th May 1936, Amma's wedding took place at Bapatla with [[Brahmandam Nageswara Rao]] who became later the [[Karanam|village officer]] of Jillellamudi.<ref name="ReferenceD">"[http://bhaktiprapamcham.blogspot.com/p/saints.html]", 17 February 2007, p.108</ref>
==Charitable career== At [[Jillellamudi]], as a young housewife, Amma looked after the needs of her family which came to include two sons and a daughter. In addition to performing her household duties, Amma devised and organized a grain bank to help the poor and needy. <ref>''Daughters of the Goddess: The Women Saints of India'' by [[Linda Johnson (poker player)|Linda Johnson]] (Yes International Publishers, {{ISBN|0936663-09-X}})</ref> Amma used to give food to every visitor to the village; thus she came to be known as "Mother of All" (viswajanani in Sanskrit means mother (janani) of all).
She founded the common dining hall Annapurnalayam on 15 August 1958. This place serves simple vegetarian food day and night to all who came. In 1960, the "House of All" was founded to provide lodging to the residents and visitors.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
Amma established a Sanskrit school in 1966 (now the [[Matrusri Oriental College]] and High School) and within a relatively short time, one could hear the inmates speaking [[Sanskrit]] fluently.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eduhelp.in/institute/College/4062-Matrusri%20Oriental%20College |title=Matrusri Oriental College(MOC), Jillellamudi | College | Arts |publisher=eduhelp.in |date= |accessdate=2016-03-03}}</ref>
Amma saw only good in people and had no concept of "sin", treating all alike irrespective of faith and religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gurusfeet.com/guru/mathrusri-anasuya-devi|title=Mathrusri Anasuya Devi - Gurusfeet.com|publisher=}}</ref>
==Death== Amma died on 12 June 1985.<ref name="Reference1"/> A temple Anasuyeswaralayam was built, in which a life size statue of Amma was installed in 1987.
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.viswajanani.org/}} * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/31313457/Viswajanani-Amma-Jillellamudi] {{authority control}} {{Portalbar|Hinduism|Indian religions|India}}

{{Infobox person | name =André Chave | image =Chave-buste.JPG | image_size = | caption =Bust of André Chave by André-Joseph Allar on the corner of Boulevard Chave and Place Jean Jaurès in Marseille | birth_name = | birth_date =1799 | birth_place = | death_date =1868 | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality =French | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation =Landowner
Real estate developer | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children =Nicolas Chave | parents = | relatives = | box_width = }} '''André Chave''' (1799-1868) was a [[France|French]] landowner and real estate developer in [[Marseille]].[http://www.marseille.fr/sitevdm/document?id=9911&id_attribute=48 Marseille] [[File:Marseille - Tramway - Boulevard Chave (7668163946).jpg|thumb|Boulevard Chave in Marseille]] ==Early life== André Chave was born in 1799. ==Career== A major landowner of agricultural fields, he became a real estate developer as the city of Marseille grew.Jean-Jacques Jordi, Jean-Claude Izzo, Anne-Marie Lapillonne, Jean-Claude Izzo, ''Marseille'', Autrement, 1998, p. 220 [https://books.google.com/books?id=84MnAQAAMAAJ&q=%22nicolas+chave%22+marseille&dq=%22nicolas+chave%22+marseille&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gvWfUryyCs7b7Abyg4D4AQ&ved=0CFEQ6AEwBA]Laurence Lemaire, ''Les gens de Marseille font le guide'', Images en Manoeuvres Editions, 2003, p. 60 As explained on his public bust, he developed the neighbourhood of [[Le Camas]], and what later came to be known as the [[Boulevard Chave]], both in the [[5th arrondissement of Marseille]].Dominique Auzias, Jean-Paul Labourdette, ''Guide de l'habitat Marseille'', [[Le Petit Futé]], 2012, p. 65 [https://books.google.com/books?id=BwQ9NXEn9ccC&pg=PA65] ==Personal life== He had a son, [[Nicolas Chave]], who inherited the neighbourhood developed by his father.[https://books.google.com/books?id=ITkrAQAAIAAJ&q=%22nicolas+chave%22+marseille&dq=%22nicolas+chave%22+marseille&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gvWfUryyCs7b7Abyg4D4AQ&ved=0CFkQ6AEwBQ Maurice Gontard, ''Histoire des lycées de Marseille'', Édisud, 1982] He commissioned architect [[Gaudensi Allar]] (1841-1904) to build a private residence on the corner of the Boulevard Chave and the Place Jean Jaurès.Pierre Guiral, Félix Reynaud, ''Les Marseillais dans l'histoire'', Privat, 1988, p. 83 [https://books.google.com/books?id=cvghAQAAIAAJ&q=%22nicolas+chave%22+marseille&dq=%22nicolas+chave%22+marseille&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gvWfUryyCs7b7Abyg4D4AQ&ved=0CF8Q6AEwBg] The architect's brother, [[André-Joseph Allar]] (1845-1926), designed a bust of his father, which is still displayed there.[http://www.culturecommunication.gouv.fr/Regions/Drac-Paca/Politique-culturelle/Conservation-regionale-des-monuments-historiques/Monuments-commemoratifs/Les-auteurs French Ministry of Culture: Les auteurs] ==Death== He died in 1868. ==Legacy== *The Boulevard Chave in Marseille is named in his honour.[https://maps.google.co.uk/maps?oe=utf-8&client=firefox-a&channel=np&q=boulevard+chave,+marseille&ie=UTF-8&hq=&hnear=0x12c9bf5ee215e033:0xa7995eb632ecd145,Boulevard+Chave,+Marseille,+France&gl=uk&ei=YtSfUoWzGZOBhAe5hoEI&ved=0CEEQ8gEwAQ Google Maps] It stretches from the [[Place Jean-Jaurès]] to [[Gare de Marseille-Blancarde]]. *The Théâtre Chave, a theatre near the Place Jean-Jaurès, was established in 1840; it closed down shortly after.Pierre Echinard, ''L'espace du spectacle à Marseille, deux siècles d'évolution'', 1991, issue 73, pp. 39-46 [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/medit_0025-8296_1991_num_73_2_2716] *The Prison Chave was a jail on the corner of Rue Georges and Boulevard Chave.[http://www.tourisme-marseille.com/ancienne-prison-chave-de-marseille.html Marseille Tourism: Ancienne Prison Chave, Marseille] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150521201607/http://www.tourisme-marseille.com/ancienne-prison-chave-de-marseille.html |date=May 21, 2015 }} Built in 1852, all capital punishment executions in Marseille were carried out in front of this jail from 1912 to 1934. During World War II, it was used to jail Jews and members of the [[French Resistance]], who published the newspaper ''L’Aube de la Liberté''. It was demolished in 1958. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chave, Andre}} [[Category:1799 births]] [[Category:1868 deaths]] [[Category:People from Marseille]] [[Category:Landowners]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{about||the "Orang Bukit" ethnic group of the Dayak Klemantan people branch|Ukit people|the "Orang Bukit" ethnic group of the Dayak [[Ot Danum people]] branch|Meratus Dayak}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = '''Bukitan people'''
Beketan / Bakatan / Ketan / Manketa |image = [[File:Sarawak; a Bakatan tribesman. Photograph. Wellcome V0037433.jpg|250px]] |caption = A Bakatan tribesman from [[Sarawak]], [[Malaysia]]. |population = |popplace = '''[[Borneo]]:''' |region1 = {{flag|Malaysia}} ([[Sarawak]]) |pop1 = 289 (2000) |ref1 = {{cite book|editor=Raymond G. Gordon Jr.|title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Fifteenth edition|year=2005|publisher=SIL International|isbn=1-55671-159-X}} |region2 = {{flag|Indonesia}} ([[East Kalimantan]]) |pop2 = 700 |ref2 = {{cite web|url=https://joshuaproject.net/people_groups/10768/ID |title=Beketan in Indonesia |publisher=[[Joshua Project]] |accessdate=2017-07-22}} |langs = [[Bukitan language]], [[Malay language]] ([[Sarawakian Malay]]), [[Malaysian English]] |rels = [[Christianity]] (predominantly), [[Animism]] |related = [[Ukit people]], Sian, Kejaman, Sekapan and Lahanan }} '''Bukitan''' (also known as '''Baketan''') is a small tribe living in the state of [[Sarawak]], [[Malaysia]] and [[East Kalimantan]] of [[Indonesia]]. They are found in [[Bintulu]] district of [[Sarawak]]. Not many of these people are left due to intermarriages with other tribes, adopting [[Iban people]] agricultural practices and way of life.{{cite book|author=Jean-Francois Bissonnette, Stephane Bernard & Rodolphe De Koninck|title=Borneo Transformed: Agricultural Expansion on the Southeast Asian Frontier|year=2011|publisher=NUS Press|isbn=9971-69-544-8}} == History == The origin of the Bukitan is from Palin, [[Kalimantan]]. They moved into [[Sarawak]] via [[Lubok Antu]] and settled there in the 19th century.{{cite book|author=Victor T. King|title=The Maloh of West Kalimantan: an ethnographic study of social inequality and social change among an Indonesian Borneo people|year=1995|publisher=Foris Publications|isbn=90-676-5065-X|page=53}} Then, in came the [[Iban people|Iban]]s from [[Kapuas Hulu|Kapuas]] (in [[Kalimantan]]), a powerful [[headhunting]] tribe at that time, attacking them and chasing them out of their homeland.{{cite book|author=Traude Gavin|title=Iban Ritual Textiles|year=2004|publisher=NUS Press|isbn=99-716-9294-5|page=4}}{{cite book|editor=Vinson H. Sutlive & Joanne Sutlive|title=The Encyclopaedia of Iban Studies: O-Z|year=2001|publisher=Tun Jugah Foundation|isbn=98-340-5133-6|page=1593}} They fled to [[Saribas]] which is what is now in the [[Betong Division]]. There, they settled and built their community. During those years, they co-existed with the Ibans, after a peace sealed by the marriage of the daughter of their leader [[Entinggi]] to the son of the Iban chief [[Tindin]].{{cite book|author=Barau Anak Gelayan|editor=Nalong Anak Buda|title=Betie Tajak Ngakak Tajai Ngelayang|year=2016|publisher=Johnny Anak Chuat|isbn=967-10174-8-7}} After many years, due to some misunderstandings, war broke out with the Ibans and they lost. They again fled to various places before settling in [[Sungai Merit]], a tributary of Batang Tatau river in [[Bintulu]] division and its vicinity until today.{{cite book|editor=Vinson H. Sutlive & Joanne Sutlive|title=The Encyclopaedia of Iban Studies: A-G|year=2001|publisher=Tun Jugah Foundation|isbn=98-340-5131-X|page=321}} Evidence of Bukitan existence can be found in areas such as the Saribas ([[Ulu Paku|Paku]], [[Layar]] and [[Rimbas]]){{cite book|author=Rob A. Cramb|title=Land and Longhouse: Agrarian Transformation in the Uplands of Sarawak|year=2007|publisher=NIAS Press|isbn=87-7694-010-1}} and [[Lubok Antu]] in the form of [[burial grounds]], name of places and ancient [[orchards]]. ==Notable people== * Jonathan Tinggang Ngabang, a high jumper Malaysian athlete.{{cite web|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2014/06/03/host-state-treats-sarawak-athletes-to-gawai-gathering/ |title=Host state treats Sarawak athletes to Gawai gathering |publisher=The Borneo Post |date=3 June 2014 |accessdate=2015-08-26}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Ethnic groups in Malaysia}} {{Portal bar|Indonesia|Malaysia|Society}} [[Category:Dayak people]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Malaysia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Sarawak]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use British English|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Cal Henderson | image = Cal Henderson CC-BY.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Callum James Henderson-Begg | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|df=yes|17 January 1981}} | birth_place = | nationality = British | education = | occupation = computer programmer, author | known_for = }}
'''Callum James Henderson-Begg''' (born 17 January 1981), known as '''Cal Henderson''', is a British computer [[programmer]] and author based in [[San Francisco]].
==Education== Henderson attended [[Sharnbrook Upper School and Community College]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sharnbrook.beds.sch.uk/cal-henderson-is-the-cofounder-of-the-san-franciscobased-tiny-speck/14486.html |title= Cal Henderson is the co-founder of the San Francisco-based Tiny Speck |date= June 2014|website= Sharnbrook Upper School}}</ref>, and [[Birmingham City University]] where he graduated with a degree in software engineering in 2002.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bcu.ac.uk/news-events/news/slack-co-founder-cal-henderson-urges-graduates-to-be-their-own-boss|title=Slack co-founder Cal Henderson urges graduates to be their own boss|website=Birmingham City University|language=en|access-date=2017-11-01}}</ref>
== Career == Henderson is best known as the co-founder and [[chief technology officer]] at [[Slack (software)|Slack]], as well as co-owning and developing the online creative community [[B3ta]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/blackcountry/features/2003/08/rob_manuel/rob_manuel.shtml |title= Interview with B3ta co-founder Rob Manuel |date= August 2005 |accessdate= 2007-06-12 |publisher= BBC}}</ref> with Denise Wilton and [[Rob Manuel]]; being the chief software architect for the photo-sharing application [[Flickr]]<ref name="techrep">{{cite web|url=https://www.techrepublic.com/article/cal-henderson-slack-cto-author-science-fiction-fan/ |title= Cal Henderson: Slack CTO. Author. Science fiction fan. | last= Forrest|first=Conner| work=TechRepublic | date=13 April 2015}}</ref> (originally working for [[Ludicorp]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2014/08/the-most-fascinating-profile-youll-ever-read-about-a-guy-and-his-boring-startup/|title=The Most Fascinating Profile You’ll Ever Read About a Guy and His Boring Startup|last=Honan|first=Mat|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-05-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= The Team: Web Development Lead: Cal Henderson |url= http://www.ludicorp.com/team_member.php?id=15 |publisher= Ludicorp |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20040211201515/http://www.ludicorp.com/team_member.php?id=15 |archivedate= 2004-02-11}}</ref> and then [[Yahoo]]) and writing the book ''Building Scalable Web Sites''<ref name="oreilly.com">{{cite web| title =O'Reilly catalog - Building Scalable Web Sites |url= http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/web2apps/ |accessdate= 2007-06-12 |publisher= O'Reilly Media}}</ref> for [[O'Reilly Media]].
He has also worked for [[EMAP]] as their technical director of special web projects<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=29202800&privcapId=21766888&previousCapId=21766888&previousTitle=LudiCorp%2520Research%2520and%2520Development%2520Ltd.|title=Cal Henderson: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-05-04}}</ref> and is responsible for writing City Creator<ref>{{cite web |title= City Creator - Yahoo! picks for September 16, 2003 |url= http://picks.yahoo.com/picks/i/20030916.html |publisher= Yahoo! |accessdate= 2007-06-12}}</ref> among many other websites, services and desktop applications. Cal was the co-founder and VP of engineering at [[Tiny Speck]],<ref name="tinyspeck">{{cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/stewart-butterfields-tiny-speck-team/ | title= Stewart Butterfield's Tiny Speck team | work= cnet.com | date= 9 February 2010}}</ref> the company whose internal tool transitioned into Slack.
Henderson's connection to [[Stewart Butterfield]] and Slack began through a game developed by Butterfield's first company, Ludicorp, called ''Game Neverending''. He ran a fan website dedicated to the game and broke into an internal Ludicorp mailing list. Instead of repercussions, Butterfield hired Henderson to work for his company.<ref name=":0" />
== Personal life == Henderson is [[color blind]], and has worked on applications to make the web more accessible to the color blind.<ref name="techrep"></ref> He is also a frequent contributor to [[open-source software]] projects and runs a number of utility websites, such as Unicodey, to make certain programming tasks easier.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.iamcal.com Personal website] * [https://github.com/iamcal GitHub contributions] * [http://www.webuser.co.uk/carsonworkshops/CalHenderson.mp3 2006 Future of Web Apps Talk]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Henderson, Cal}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:British bloggers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Web developers]] [[Category:Computer programmers]] [[Category:People educated at Sharnbrook Academy]] [[Category:People with color blindness]]

{{multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=June 2013}} {{Orphan|date=October 2012}} {{cleanup reorganize|date=August 2018}} }}
'''Christian Sulheim''' (born 5 August 1952) is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] cultural heritage conservationist, farmer and businessman.<ref name="Nbl"> {{cite encyclopedia|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Christian_Sulheim/utdypning|title=Christian Sulheim|last=Berg|first=Rolf Y|authorlink=Rolf Yngvar Berg|encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|language=Norwegian|accessdate=13 July 2012}}</ref>
==Biography== Christian Sulheim, also known as Christian Grindvold Sulheim Born: August 5, 1952 Home: Lom, Oppland County, Norway Occupation: Conservator of cultural heritage, farmer and businessman. Parents: Kolbjorn Torleiv Grindvold (1919-2002), and Agnes Valde (1922-2009 ). Married May 14, 1977 to Magnhild Bakken (born June 29, 1952), daughter of Jon Bakken (born 1925) and Oddbjorg Silseth (born 1926). >
Christian Sulheim operates one of Norway’s oldest family owned manor farms, Uppigard Sulheim in [[Bøverdalen]] near Lom. Since 1983 he has been the leading advocate for private owners of government designated cultural heritage sites. He has also pioneered efforts to increase recognition of Norway’s rich cultural heritage by establishing the Norwegian Heritage Foundation and serving as its director for many years. >
Sulheim grew up on the family farm as one of seven children and its designated heir. Educated as an [[Agronomy|agronomist]], he interned on several large farms in [[Germany]]. After graduation, he began studying law but his studies were interrupted in 1980 when he took over Sulheim after his father retired. Government regulations governing historically preserved farm buildings and the consequent burden the state placed on their owners struck him as profoundly unfair. This caused him to appeal to Norway’s Prime Minister for help. >
In 1983 Sulheim formed an association of owners of buildings protected by cultural heritage preservation laws in northern [[Gudbrandsdalen]], whom he describes as "the loyal unpaid security guards in Norway's largest museum." He led the association until 1992, making sure that owners of cultural heritage sites were well represented in the nation’s political arena. During this time he continued his studies, mostly on his own. In 1988, he submitted his thesis in history at the University of Trondheim: Sulheim, a preserved farm, 1923-1978. How does the Cultural Heritage Act function in relation to private ownership? In 2000 he received a [[Master’s Degree]] (Cand. Mag.) from the [[University of Oslo]]. >
In 1988 Sulheim in association with the Oppland County Municipal Affairs Department established a Rural District Cultural Arts Center in the [[Vågå]] district dedicated to training and expanding employment opportunities in cultural heritage preservation. As the center's director, Sulheim initiated the first formal vocational training program focusing on the construction and maintenance of traditional log buildings. He was also able to travel throughout Europe to study the interactions between governments and private owners of protected cultural resources. In 1989 he founded a corporation called Top of Norway which worked with Star Tours and thirty other companies to facilitate and organize cultural tourism in Norway. >
In 1993 Sulheim established the Norwegian Heritage Foundation, with assistance from the Ministry of Municipal Government, For ten hectic years he served as the foundation’s director. His efforts resulted in establishing a quality certification program called "Olavsrosa" (Olav’s Praise), a “Take Action” program that saved an estimated 1,800 old houses, and authoring two books: Norwegian Heritage: A maintenance manual for owners of preserved houses, and Norwegian Heritage, a practical guidebook. He also established an exhibit entitled "Cultural Heritage” in Norway’s information center in Oslo and a journal, Cultural Heritage. In addition, between 1997 and 1990, he contributed nearly 1000 radio, television, newspaper and magazine programs, and journal articles on behalf of the Norwegian Heritage Foundation. >
Sulheim started a rural revolt against the slow-moving and unhelpful cultural heritage bureaucracy in Oslo. He clearly and bluntly argued that “The government’s position on heritage conservation is a political disaster, a catastrophe and a huge step backward," and that cultural heritage is far too important to be left to government to deal with alone. Cultural heritage site owners also have a right to be heard. He further argued that politicians should look at cultural heritage taxation policy in a broader context: "If I allow my houses to deteriorate, I break the law, but for every nail I pound in, I have to pay sales tax." Also, a sustainable cultural heritage approach must accept use as an important factor: "I don’t want my farm to be like an old wooden spoon, something people can look at, but can’t use.” He realized early on that government can’t afford to protect Norway’s cultural heritage sites forever by itself. Accordingly, he further argued that if we want to take care of the cultural heritage that we are so proud of, we will need a supportive commercial apparatus as well. Christian Sulheim has succeeded in changing and improving laws and regulations affecting cultural heritage in Norway. Sulheim has also contributed to the local history of Lom, where he contributed the portrait Torgeir T. Garmo and fire protection measures for the Lom stave church. >
Sulheim has served on the boards and/or agencies of the following organizations: the Society for the Preservation of Norway’s Ancient Monuments, the Oppland County government, the World Wildlife Fund in Norway and the Royal Norwegian Society for Development. In 1999 he was appointed to the society’s Cultural Committee by Norway’s Ministry of the Environment. Beyond Norway, Sulheim has served as Vice President of the Network of National Heritage Organizations since 2000. He was a board member of CHAIN, European Development Project for cultural information, and he led the Norwegian cultural delegation to the United States to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Sons of Norway. He has given over 600 lectures in 15 different countries, including as a guest lecturer at the University of Trento, Italy and to the Russian Parliament. >
Sulheim has received numerous awards: The Society for the Preservation of Norwegian Ancient Monuments, Order of Urnes, Lorentzen Fund prize, the Norwegian Farmers’ Association Weekly Common Sense Award, and the Dobloug Order of the Polar Star. In 1996 he received Britain’s Prince Philip Medal of Honor, and in 2001 he was elected as the first honorary member of the National Trust of Russia. >
2001-2006 Christian Sulheim served as Vice President of ICA Norway, the Norwegian branch of one of the Nordic region’s leading retail companies. 2007–present, as General Manager of the tourism company Top of Norway (ton) >
==Publications== * La oss få eit kompetansesenter i Vågå for freda gardar på landet, (Let us have a center for assuring the competent treatment of farms designated as historic landmarks) nr. 6(3), Otta, 1987, p. 12. * Sulheim, en fredet gård, 1923–1978. Hvordan fungerer kulturminneloven i forhold til private eiere? (Sulheim a historic landmark farm 1923-1978. How does the cultural preservation law impact private owners). Thesis. University of Trondheim, 1988. * Regionalt PTD-projekt 16. “Vernesenter for bygdekultur”, oppfølgingssøknad til Kommunaldepartementet (Regional PTD Project 16. Center for the Preservation of Rural Culture, " an application to the Ministry of Local Government, Vågåmo 1989). * Kulturminnevernet må setjast inn i større samanheng (The Center for the Preservation of Rural Culture must be viewed in broad context). In Aftenposten. Nov. 16,1989. * Privat tjenesteyting i distriktene. Vernesenter for bygdekultur, prosjektrapport til Kommunaldepartementet (Private services in rural areas. Preservation Centre for Rural Culture, project report to the Ministry of Local Government) Vågå/Lom 1990. * Norsk Kulturarv. Praktisk informasjon (Norwegian Cultural Inheritance: Practical information), Vågå 1996. * Kulturminnevern – har Norge råd til det? (A Cultural Preservation Corps – Can Norway afford it?) In Aftenposten. March 16, 1998. * Norsk Kulturarv. Ei praktisk reisehåndbok (Norwegian Cultural Inheritance: A practical travel handbook) K. Aarstrand. editor, Vågå 1998. * Arson in Norway. Installation of a fire protection system in the Vågå church, in Europa Nostra (Haag) nr. 2/2000, p. 27–28. * Torgeir T., A. Brimi og J. Rørdam: Det høieste høie. 10 originaler fra Jotunheimen,(The Highest of the High: Ten originals from Jotunheimen). Lysaker 2002, p. 96–97. * Særmerknad fra utvalgsmedlemmene Elin Schanche og Christian Sulheim (Remarks from selected members: Elin Schanche and Christian Sulheim), Chapter 15 in NOU 2002:1
===About Christian Sulheim=== * M. Kollandsrud: “Fredning er ei det beste – men at man får noe til. Hverdag i fredet hus – slik eieren opplever det”, (Preservation is not the best unless the owner benefits in some way from maintaining a preserved building) in Fortidsvern nr. 4/1982, s. 3–7. * T. Ness: “De fredet våre gårder. Hær av trofaste vaktmestere”(They preserved our farms: An army of loyal guards), in Aftenposten. July 3, 1984 * L. Elton: “Kulturisme. Kulturarven trenger et kommersielt apparat” (Culturalism: Cultural heritage needs a commercial mechanism), in Nærings Eiendom nr. November 1993, p. 73–76. * E. Odden: “Kultur på rot og penger på bok. Olavsrosa som kvalitetsstempel” (Culture at the root and money in the book: Olavsrosa as a temple of quality), in Dagningen November 15, 1994. * H. Sandvig: “En folkereisning for kulturvern. Som skåret ut av folkeeventyret” (A folk movement for cultural preservation: As if cut from folktale), in Aftenposten. March 25,.1995. * R. Bistrup: “Kulturfreak fra fjellheimen” (Culture freak from the mountain home), in Aftenposten. August 2, .1997. * E. Odden: “Christian på russisk – en reise” (Christian in Russian – a journey), in Gudbrandsdølen Dagningen March 31,.2001. * K. Korsvold: “Bonde for sin butikk. Han er gått over til fienden, fjellbonden og kulturforkjemperen Christian Sulheim” (Farmer for his commerce: He has gone over to the enemy, the mountain farmer and culture warrior Christian Sulheim), in Aftenposten August 10, .2002.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox fashion designer |name = Didit Hediprasetyo |image = |caption = |nationality = Indonesian |birth_name=Ragowo Hedi Prasetyo Djojohadikusumo |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1984|03|22}} |birth_place = [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]] |death_date = |death_place = |parents= [[Prabowo Subianto Djojohadikusumo]]
[[Siti Hediyati Hariyadi|Titiek Soeharto]] |relatives= [[Sumitro Djojohadikusumo]] (paternal grandfather)
[[Soeharto]] (maternal grandfather)
[[Siti Hartinah]] (maternal grandmother)
[[Hashim Djojohadikusumo]] (paternal uncle)
[[Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana|Tutut Suharto]] (maternal aunt)
[[Tommy Suharto]] (maternal uncle)
[[J. Soedradjad Djiwandono]] (uncle in law)
[[Probosutedjo]] (step-granduncle) |education = [[Parsons The New School for Design]]
([[Parsons Paris]]){{cite web|url=http://www.didithediprasetyo.com/#|title=Didit Hediprasetyo|work=Didit Hediprasetyo Official Website|accessdate=27 June 2015}} |label_name = Didit Hediprasetyo |significant_design= |awards = Silver Thimble Award of [[Parsons Paris (2013)|Parsons Paris]] |}} '''Didit Hediprasetyo''' (born March 22, 1984) is a [[Paris]]-based [[Indonesia]]n [[fashion designer]]{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/fashion/spring-summer-2014/couture/didit-hediprasetyo|title=Didit Hediprasetyo Spring/Summer 2014|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|accessdate=27 June 2015}} and [[socialite]]. The only son of 2014 Indonesian Presidential election candidate, [[Prabowo Subianto Djojohadikusumo]] and [[Siti Hediyati Hariyadi|Titiek Soeharto]], the daughter of second president of Indonesia, [[Soeharto]]. He is the second designer after [[Karl Lagerfeld]] and the first Asian designer to design the interior and exterior of [[BMW]] Individual Series 7 which produced only five units around the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.press.bmwgroup.com/asia/pressDetail.html;jsessionid=jhMLVPlMbVXs5L6mJ882GLMz5tMGJ4JypkvvnLr9nFRKP9L5pJFC!1963000652?title=consummate-luxury-the-bmw-individual-7-series-by-didit-hediprasetyo&outputChannelId=16&id=T0127439EN&left_menu_item=node__4307|title=Consummate luxury: the BMW Individual 7 Series by Didit Hediprasetyo.|publisher=BMWGroup.com |date= |accessdate=June 28, 2015}} He rose to the international prominence after his first design show on [[Paris Fashion Week|Paris Couture Fashion Week]] Spring/Summer 2010. ==Early life== Hediprasetyo was born in [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]], the only son of [[Prabowo Subianto]],{{cite web|url=http://gaya.tempo.co/read/news/2014/05/29/110581101/Didit-Hediprasetyo-Putra-Prabowo-yang-Mendunia/ |title=Didit Hediprasetyo, Putra Prabowo yang Mendunia |publisher=Tempo.co |date= |accessdate=June 28, 2015}} former commander of [[Kopassus]] and [[Kostrad]] of Indonesia, businessman and the candidate of [[Indonesian presidential election, 2014|2014 Indonesian presidential election]] from [[Great Indonesia Movement Party]] (GERINDRA){{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/06/17/son-s-presence-brings-out-prabowo-s-fatherly-side.html|title=Son’s presence brings out Prabowo’s fatherly side|work=[[The Jakarta Post]]|accessdate=27 June 2015}} and [[Titiek Soeharto]], the daughter of Indonesia's second president, [[Soeharto]] and [[Siti Hartinah]]. From his father side, he is the grandson of [[Sumitro Djojohadikusumo]], a prominent economist, Minister of Industry and Trade (1950-1951) and Minister of Finance of Indonesia (1952-1953 and 1955-1956). He is also the paternal nephew of the 39th richest person of Indonesia, [[Hashim Djojohadikusumo]]{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/hashim-djojohadikusumo/|title=#39 Hashim Djojohadikusumo|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=27 June 2015}} and the maternal nephew of a businessman and socialite [[Tommy Suharto]]. Since childhood, Hediprasetyo always wanted to learn many things that it was difficult for him to choose his study. He wanted to be a painter, photographer, historian, theatre director and businessman. He then joined a [[Shakespeare]] theatre workshop at [[Harvard Extension School]]. This is the beginning of his interest in fashion and then he took fashion design major. He graduated from the [[Parsons Paris]] in 2007. To enrich his knowledge, he took painting, photography and art history courses.https://swa.co.id/youngster-inc/self-employed/didit-hediprasetyo-jejak-emas-di-runway-dunia ==Career== The designer presented his first Spring/Summer 2010 couture show in the salons of the Hotel Crillon in January 2010, offering corseted gowns and fitted skirts and shorts, and has since regularly presented collections during Couture week. "I’m trying to focus on younger clientele and offer them couture with a modern twist," he said in 2012,Kolesnikov-Jessop, Sonia (February 2012), [https://couturenotebook.com/couture-news/interview-didit-hediprasetyo-couture Didit Hediprasetyo - The Interview], couturenotebook.com "My ideal woman is someone who is very cultured, who understands the east and west cultures and who appreciates the aesthetic of the old days of couture, but who at the same time doesn’t take it too seriously. She lives in a realistic world. She might be wearing couture going for a coffee with a friend or going to the beach wearing a simple tank top and short." Hediprasetyo often gives a nod to his Indonesian origins by including Songket, a traditional hand woven Indonesian brocade, in his collections.Kolesnikov-Jessop, Sonia (January 2014) [https://couturenotebook.com/couture-news/didit-hediprasetyo-gives-songket-a-houndstooth-twist-for-ss-2014 Spring 2014 Haute Couture: Didit Hediprasetyo Gives Songket a Houndstooth Twist], couturenotebook.com ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.didithediprasetyo.com Official website] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hediprasetyo, Didit}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:People from Jakarta]] [[Category:People from Paris]] [[Category:Javanese people]] [[Category:Minahasa people]] [[Category:Banyumasan people]] [[Category:Indonesian fashion designers]] [[Category:Indonesian socialites]] [[Category:Cendana family]] [[Category:Djojohadikusumo family]] [[Category:Parsons The New School for Design alumni]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Edwin Waller | image = Pattison TX Judge Waller Marker.jpg | image_size = 270px | caption = Judge Edwin Waller historical marker is west of [[Pattison, Texas]] at FM 1458 and Buller Road. | birth_name = | birth_date = November 4, 1800 | birth_place = [[Spotsylvania County, Virginia]] | death_date = January 3, 1881 | death_place = [[Austin, Texas]] | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Texas State Cemetery]] | resting_place_coordinates = | spouse = | children = | parents = | signature = }}
'''Edwin Waller''' (November 4, 1800 – January 3, 1881) was an entrepreneur, signer of the [[Texas Declaration of Independence]], the first [[mayor of Austin, Texas]], and the designer of its downtown [[grid plan]].
==Texas independence== He was born in [[Spotsylvania County, Virginia]], United States, in 1800 to a family settled in the state since colonial times when they emigrated from [[Buckinghamshire, England]]. His family later settled in [[Missouri]].
In April 1831, he immigrated to the [[Mexico|Mexican]] state of [[Coahuila y Tejas]]. On July 20, he received a land grant from the government in present-day [[Brazoria County, Texas|Brazoria County]]. He began a shipping business, transporting cotton from [[Velasco, Texas]], to [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], using his ship, the ''Sabine'', and was once briefly arrested in Velasco for refusing to pay Mexican customs duty.
He very quickly became active in the movement for Texas independence from Mexico. On June 26, 1832, he fought and was wounded at the [[Battle of Velasco]], an early skirmish in the [[Texas Revolution]]. In 1833, he became the [[alcade]] of Brazoria Municipality. In 1835, he represented the Columbia Municipality at the Consultation in San Felipe de Austin, where he was chosen by the members to serve in the General Council of the Provisional Government of Texas.
On February 1, 1836, he was elected as the Brazoria delegate to the [[Convention of 1836]] in [[Washington-on-the-Brazos, Texas|Washington-on-the-Brazos]], where he signed the newly adopted [[Texas Declaration of Independence]] on March 2. At the convention, he served on the committee that helped draft the Constitution of the [[Republic of Texas]].
==Other pursuits== In 1839, he was chosen by Texas President [[Mirabeau Lamar]] to survey the site, sell lots, and erect public buildings for the new state capital in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]]. The original landsite for the capital was narrowed to 640 acres (2.6 km²) that fronted the [[Colorado River (Texas)|Colorado River]] between two creeks, [[Shoal Creek (Texas)|Shoal Creek]] and [[Waller Creek]], which was later named in his honor. The fourteen-block [[grid plan]] was bisected by a broad north-south thoroughfare, [[Congress Avenue]], running up from the river to Capital Square, where the new [[Texas State Capitol]] was to be constructed. A temporary one-story capitol was erected on the corner of Colorado and 8th streets. On August 1, the first auction of 306 lots was held. The grid plan that Waller designed and surveyed now forms the basis of the streets of downtown Austin.
On October 13, 1839, he offered his house for the meeting place to establish the first [[Freemasonry|Masonic Lodge]] in Austin [https://web.archive.org/web/20040404150247/http://www.austin.tx-mm.org/history.html].
On January 13, 1840, he was elected the first mayor of Austin. He resigned before the end of his term, however, and moved to Austin County. A new county formed from parts of Austin County and neighboring Grimes County was renamed [[Waller County, Texas|Waller County]] in his honor in 1873.
In 1861 Waller represented Austin County at the Texas [[secession]] convention. As one of the last living signers of the Texas Declaration of Independence, he was given the honor of signing the secession ordinance first after the convention president [[Oran Milo Roberts]].
In 1873 Waller served as the first president of the [[Texas Veterans Association]].
He died on January 3, 1881 in Austin, where he moved shortly before his death to live with one of his daughters. He was buried in Waller County, but his remains were later moved to the [[Texas State Cemetery]] in Austin.
==External links== *{{Handbook of Texas|id=fwa38|name=Edwin Waller}} *[http://www.cemetery.state.tx.us/pub/user_form.asp?step=1&pers_id=110 Texas State Cemetery: Edwin Waller] *[http://texashistory.unt.edu/permalink/meta-pth-5827:70 Entry for Edwin Waller]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} from the [https://archive.is/20121205004737/http://texashistory.unt.edu/permalink/meta-pth-5827 ''Biographical Encyclopedia of Texas''] published 1880, hosted by the [http://texashistory.unt.edu/ Portal to Texas History.] *[https://archive.is/20130117083324/http://austinlodge12.com/history.html History of Austin Lodge #12] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040618180738/http://www.klru.org/austinhistory/history.html KLRU: Austin History] *[http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/rbw11 Waller Creek] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040206025303/http://www.tamu.edu/ccbn/dewitt/consultations6.htm Texian Independence Convention Delegates] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=XQ62W7SnzeYC&pg=PA235 Texas, the Dark Corner of the Confederacy: Contemporary Accounts of the Lone Star State in the Civil War]''. U of Nebraska Press; 1994 [Retrieved 6 August 2017]. {{ISBN|0-8032-7036-4}}. p. 235–237.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Waller, Edwin}} [[Category:1800 births]] [[Category:1881 deaths]] [[Category:People from Houston]] [[Category:People of the Texas Revolution]] [[Category:Mayors of Austin, Texas]] [[Category:People from Spotsylvania County, Virginia]] [[Category:Burials at Texas State Cemetery]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox scientist |name =Evelyn Beauchamp |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Evelyn Leonora Almina Herbert |birth_date = {{birth date|1901|8|15|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Highclere Castle]], [[Hampshire]], England |death_date = {{death date|1980|1|31|df=y}} (aged 79) |death_place = [[London]], England |nationality = British |spouse = {{marriage|[[Brograve Beauchamp]]|1923|1976|end={{abbr|d.|died}}}} |children = One daughter |field = |known_for = Present at the opening of [[KV62|Tutankhamun's tomb]] }} '''Lady Evelyn Leonora Almina Beauchamp''' ({{nee|'''Herbert'''}}; 15 August 1901 – 31 January 1980) was the daughter of [[George Herbert, 5th Earl of Carnarvon]]. In November 1922, she, her father and the archaeologist [[Howard Carter]] were the first people in modern times to enter both the [[KV62|tomb]] and inner burial chamber of the Egyptian Pharaoh [[Tutankhamun]]. She later married Sir [[Brograve Beauchamp]] and had a daughter. Lady Evelyn died in 1980, at the age of 79. ==Early life== Lady Evelyn Leonora Almina Herbert was born on 15 August 1901, the second child and only daughter of [[George Herbert, 5th Earl of Carnarvon]] and [[Almina Herbert, Countess of Carnarvon]]. Her older brother is [[Henry Herbert, 6th Earl of Carnarvon]]. Lady Evelyn was launched as a [[debutante]] and presented at court in 1919. In the winters of 1921 and 1922, she accompanied her parents to [[Cairo]] where they attended receptions at the High Commission Residency during the Cairo seasons of 1921 and 1922. It was here that she met her future husband, [[Brograve Beauchamp]], the son of the Liberal MP Sir [[Edward Beauchamp]], who continued to visit her when they both returned to England.{{Cite book|author=William Cross.|title=Carnarvon, Carter and Tutankhamun Revisited: The Hidden Truths and Doomed Relationships.|page=48-9 Published by author. 2016|isbn=9781905914364}}{{cite web|title= Lady Evelyn Herbert : Debutante of 1920|url= http://evelyn-beauchamp.blogspot.co.uk/2016/09/}} [[File: Howard Carter, Lord Carnarvon and Lady Evelyn Herbert at Tutankhamen's tomb.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Lord Carnarvon, Lady Evelyn Herbert and Howard Carter at the top of the steps leading to the newly discovered tomb of Tutankhamun, November 1922.Harry Burton’s photos of Tutankhamun’s Tomb, Griffith Institute Archive.]] ==Tutankhamun's Tomb== Lord and Lady Carnarvon often spent the winter in Egypt, where they bought antiquities for their collection in England. In 1906 Lord Carnarvon obtained a concession to excavate a site near [[Luxor]], and later one within the [[Valley of the Kings]].{{Cite book|author=Bill Price.|title=Tutankhamun, Egypt's Most Famous Pharaoh.|page=119-128. Published Pocket Essentials, Hertfordshire. 2007|isbn=9781842432402}} From 1907, Lord Carnarvon employed [[Howard Carter]] to supervise the excavation work.{{cite book|author=H. V. F. Winstone|title=Howard Carter and the discovery of the tomb of Tutankhamun|location=Manchester|publisher=Barzan|edition=rev.|year=2006|isbn=1-905521-04-9}} By 1922 little of significance had been found and Lord Carnarvon decided this would be the final year he would fund the work.{{cite book|first=Fiona|last=Carnarvon|title=Highclere Castle|publisher=Highclere Enterprises|year=2011|page=59}} However on 4 November 1922, Carter was able to send a telegram to Lord Carnarvon, in England at the time, saying:
"At last have made wonderful discovery in Valley; a magnificent tomb with seals intact; re-covered same for your arrival; congratulations". Lady Evelyn accompanied her father, and by 24 November 1922 both had arrived in Egypt and were present when the full extent of the stairway to the [[KV62|tomb]] was cleared and a seal containing the [[Pharaoh]] [[Tutankhamun]]’s [[cartouche]] was found over the doorway. This door was opened and the rubble filled corridor behind cleared, revealing the door to the main tomb.{{Cite book|author=Bill Price.|title=Tutankhamun, Egypt's Most Famous Pharaoh.|page=119-128. Published Pocket Essentials, Hertfordshire. 2007|isbn=9781842432402}} This door, and the main tomb, were to be officially opened under the supervision of the [[Supreme Council of Antiquities|Egyptian Department of Antiquities]] on 29 November. However on the 26th and 27th, Carter, his assistant Arthur Challender, Lord Carnarvon and Lady Evelyn made one or more unauthorised visits inside the tomb,{{cite web|title=Howard Carter's diary entry for 25-27 November 1922|url=http://www.griffith.ox.ac.uk/gri/4sea1not.html}}{{cite book|last=Reeves|first=C. N.|title=Valley of the Kings: the decline of a royal necropolis|location=London|publisher=Kegan Paul|year=1990|isbn=0-7103-0368-8|page=63}} becoming the first people in modern times to enter it. Challender rigged up electric lighting, illuminating a jumble of items, including gilded couches, chests, thrones, and shrines. They also found two more sealed doorways, including one to the inner burial chamber,{{cite web|title=Howard Carter's diaries 28 Oct-31 Dec 1922|url=http://www.griffith.ox.ac.uk/gri/4sea1not.html}} guarded by two life-size statues of Tutankhamun. A small hole was found in this doorway and Carter, Carnarvon and Lady Evelyn crawled through it into the inner burial chamber.{{Cite book|author=Bill Price.|title=Tutankhamun, Egypt's Most Famous Pharaoh.|page=119-128. Published Pocket Essentials, Hertfordshire. 2007|isbn=9781842432402}} The diary of Lord Carnarvon’s half-brother Mervyn Herbert,{{cite web|title=Burke's Peerage, 2003 page 699|url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p20564.htm#i205632}} although not a first-hand account, notes that Lady Evelyn, being the smallest of the party, was the first person to enter the burial chamber.{{Cite book|author=Thomas Hoving.|title=Tutankhamun: The Untold Story.|page= Cooper Square Publishing, USA. 1978|isbn=9780815411864}} Lady Evelyn and her father travelled to England in December 1922, the two returning in January 1923 to be present at the official opening of the inner burial chamber on 16 February.{{cite web|title=Howard Carter's diaries 1 Jan- 31 May 1923|url=http://www.griffith.ox.ac.uk/gri/4sea1no2.html}} The same month Brograve Beauchamp visited with his parents, Howard Carter providing a tour of Tutankhamun’s Tomb.{{cite web|title= Lady Evelyn Herbert : Debutante of 1920|url= http://evelyn-beauchamp.blogspot.co.uk/2016/09/}} Soon afterwards Lord Carnarvon contracted [[Bacteremia|blood poisoning]] and died in Cairo on 5 April 1923.{{cite news |authorlink= |title=Report of Carnarvon's death.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1923/04/05/archives/carnarvon-is-dead-of-an-insects-bite-at-pharaohs-tomb-blood.html|work=New York Times |date=5 April 1923 |accessdate=12 August 2008 }} Lady Evelyn left Egypt to return to England with [[Henry Herbert, 6th Earl of Carnarvon|her brother]], Lady Carnarvon following with Lord Carnarvon's remains a week later. This was Lady Evelyn's last visit to Egypt. She did, however, maintain contact with Howard Carter{{cite web|title=For example, Evelyn was the first person Carter visited on a 1923 trip to London, see his diary 30 May|url=http://www.griffith.ox.ac.uk/gri/4sea1no2.html}} and was present at his funeral at [[Putney Vale Cemetery]] in 1939.{{Cite book|author=William Cross.|title=Carnarvon, Carter and Tutankhamun Revisited: The Hidden Truths and Doomed Relationships.|page=97 Published by author. 2016|isbn=9781905914364}} Lady Evelyn attended the opening of the Tutankhamun 50th anniversary celebrations in 1972, including the [[Exhibitions of artifacts from the tomb of Tutankhamun#The Treasures of Tutankhamun (1972–1981)|Treasures of Tutankhamun exhibition]] at the [[British Museum]], London, where she was presented to the Queen, there to open the exhibition.{{Cite book|author=William Cross.|title=Carnarvon, Carter and Tutankhamun Revisited: The Hidden Truths and Doomed Relationships.|page=55 Published by author. 2016|isbn=9781905914364}} ==Marriage and later life== In October 1923, Lady Evelyn Herbert married [[Brograve Beauchamp]].{{cite web|title=Burke's Peerage|url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p20568.htm#i205671}} They had one child, Patricia Evelyn Beauchamp (11 July 1925 – 7 October 2014).{{cite web|title=Burke's Peerage, 1970 page 206|url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p30942.htm#i309420}} Brograve became a [[baronet]] on the death of his father in February 1925. He served as Conservative [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Walthamstow East (UK Parliament constituency)|Walthamstow East]] from 1931 to 1945,{{cite book|last=Craig|first=F. W. S.|authorlink= F. W. S. Craig|title=British Parliamentary Election Results 1918–1949|origyear=1969|edition=3rd|year=1983|publisher=Parliamentary Research Services|isbn= 0-900178-06-X |page=468}} and died 25 August 1976 at the age of 79.{{cite web|title=Burke's Peerage|url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p20568.htm#i205671}} Lady Evelyn died in London on 31 January 1980 aged 79[https://search.findmypast.co.uk/results/united-kingdom-records-in-birth-marriage-death-and-parish-records/and_civil-deaths-and-burials?firstname=evelyn&lastname=beauchamp&yearofbirth=1901&yearofbirth_offset=0&yearofdeath=1980&yearofdeath_offset=0 Birth and death records] and is buried, like her husband, at [[Putney Vale Cemetery]]. Howard Carter is also buried here.{{Cite book|author=William Cross.|title=Carnarvon, Carter and Tutankhamun Revisited: The Hidden Truths and Doomed Relationships.|page=97 Published by author. 2016|isbn=9781905914364}} ==In popular culture== Lady Evelyn Herbert has been portrayed in both films and television productions: * By [[Angharad Rees]] in the 1980 [[Columbia Pictures Television]] production ''[[The Curse of King Tut's Tomb (1980 film)|The Curse of King Tut's Tomb]]''.{{cite web|title=The Guardian 22 July 2012 Angharad Rees obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2012/jul/22/angharad-rees|accessdate=6 November 2018}} * By Alexandra Weaver in the 2005 BBC TV docudrama series ''[[Egypt (TV series)|Egypt]]'', episode two: ''The Curse of Tutankhamun''.{{cite web|title=BBC Genome: The Curse of Tutankhamun, 2005.|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/e529c0927aca4c9fb521f0c9b81998ef|accessdate=6 November 2018}} * By [[Amy Wren]] in the 2016 British ITV series [[Tutankhamun (2016 miniseries)|''Tutankhamun'']]. * In [[The Mummy (1999 film)|''The Mummy'']] the character [[List of The Mummy characters#Evelyn "Evie" Carnahan / Nefertiri|Evelyn Carnahan]] is named in tribute to Lady Evelyn Carnarvon,{{cite web|title=Radio Times.com 23 Nov 2016 Did Howard Carter and Evelyn Carnarvon have a romantic relationship?|url= http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2016-11-23/did-tutankhamuns-howard-carter-and-evelyn-carnarvon-really-have-a-romantic-relationship/|accessdate=14 January 2018}} whose father is described as one of [[Egyptology]]'s "finest patrons", and a "famous explorer". The German language novel ''Der König von Luxor'' by Philipp Vandenberg published in 2014{{cite web|title=Catalogue of the Deutschen National Bibliothek|url=https://portal.dnb.de/opac.htm?method=simpleSearch&cqlMode=true&query=idn%3D1068513756|accessdate=14 January 2018}} includes a largely fictionalised Lady Evelyn Beauchamp as one of the three principal characters.{{cite web|title=Bastei Luebbe, Publisher|url=https://www.luebbe.de/bastei-entertainment/ebooks/historische-romane/der-koenig-von-luxor/id_3333170|accessdate=14 January 2018}} ==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beauchamp (née Herbert), Lady Evelyn}} [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:English socialites]] [[Category:Herbert family]] [[Category:Tutankhamun]] [[Category:Wives of baronets]]

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Evgenia Vlasova | image = | caption = | background = solo_singer | alias = Eugenia Vlasova | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|04|08|df=yes}} |birth_place =[[Kiev]], [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukrainian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = | origin = | genre = Ukrainian pop, [[Russian pop]], [[Folk music|Folk]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[Songwriter]] | years_active = 1998–present | label = | associated_acts = [[Andru Donalds]] | website = [http://www.vlasova.com.ua/ www.vlasova.com.ua] {{uk icon}} }} '''Evgenia Vlasova''' ({{lang-uk|Євгенія Власова}}) ({{lang-ru|Евгения Власова}}) (born 8 April 1978 in [[Kiev]], [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukrainian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[singer-songwriter]].
==Biography== Her parents were artistically inclined (mother was an [[actress]], father was a singer). In 1994 Vlasova entered the R. Glier State Higher Music College, graduating in 1998. In that same year, she entered the ''Queen of the Song'' international competition in [[Rimini]], [[Italy]] singing ''Musyka dusha moya (Music of my soul)''. She won the grand prize in this event.
Also in 1998, Vlasova won several Ukrainian music popularity competitions such as the ''Song of the Year'' festival and the ''21st Century's Hope'' nomination. In 1999 she wrote "[[Wind of Hope (song)|Wind of Hope]]". [[Dmitriy Kostiuk]] signed on as her manager in that same year.
In November 2001, the ''[[Wind of Hope]]'' full-length album was released. This album was followed a string of music videos; "Severnoye siyaniye (Northern Lights)", "O Tebe (About You)", "Budu silneye (I'll be strong)", and "Plach obo mne (Cry about me)".
In 2004, Vlasova gave birth to a daughter named Nina and stepped briefly out of her singing career to devote her full attention to her new career as a mother.
Vlasova re-entered the music world in 2005, this time teaming up with [[Andru Donalds]] (a member of the group [[Enigma (musical project)|Enigma]]). The result of their work was four duets and a music video called "Limbo".
== Personal life == Vlasova is divorced from her producer Dmitry Kostyuk in 2008. They have a daughter together named Nina Kostyuk (born August 4, 2004).
== Illness == In 2009 Vlasova was diagnosed with [[ovarian cancer]]. As of March 2010 she underwent a surgery and three courses of [[chemotherapy]] and is feeling better now.
==Albums== ===Veter nadezhdy (Ветер надежды)=== *1. Ya - zhyvaja reka (Я - живая река) *2. Son (Сон) *3. Zyma (Зима) *4. Narysuju (Нарисую) *5. O tebe (О тебе - About You) *6. Dysko (Диско) *7. Veter nadezhdy (Ветер надежды - Wind of Hope) *8. Tam, gde lubov' (Там, где любовь) *9. Severnoe syjanye (Северное сияние - Northern Lights) *10. Krasnoe solnce (Красное солнце) *11. Ne zabuvaj! (Не забувай)
===Wind of Hope=== *1. Cry in the night *2. My wonderland *3. Love is a crazy game (ft. Andru Donalds) *4. Only you *5. Limbo (ft. Andru Donalds) *6. River of life *7. One night lover (ft. Andru Donalds) *8. Northern Lights *9. Gonna be stronger *10. Wind of hope (ft Andru Donalds) *11. Limbo (rmx) (ft Andru Donalds)
===Синергия (Synergy)=== *1. Лавина любви (Lavina lubvi - Avalanche of Love) *2. На двоих сердце одно… (Na dvoik cyertse adno - Two hearts as one) *3. На краю небес (Na Krayu nibyes - At the edge of Heaven) *4. Отношения (Otnoshyeniya - Relationships) *5. Планета №2 (Planeta #2 - Planet #2) *6. Нет, я не боюсь (Nyet, ya ne boyus - No, I'm not afraid) *7. Полетим в небо (Polyetim v nebo - Fly to the sky) *8. Сердце (Cyertse - Heart) *9. Шоу-тайм (Shou-Taim - Show-Time) *10. В каждом биении сердца (V kazdom biyenii certsa - Every heartbeat) *11. Убегаю (Oobegayu - Escape) *12. Шоу-тайм RMX (Shou-Taim RMX - Show-Time RMX)
==Singles== *Live River *Severnoye siyaniye (Northern Lights) *O Tebe (About You), *Budu silneye (I'll be strong) *Wind of hope (ft. [[Andru Donalds]]) *Plach obo me (Cry about me) *Limbo (ft. [[Andru Donalds]]) *Ya budu (I will) *Шоу-тайм (Show-Time) #17
<sub>''Most of the singles are in Russian and English.''</sub>

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = Mrs. | name = Fatema Akbari
{{small|{{nq|فاطمه اکبری}}}} | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Fatema | birth_date = 1974 | birth_place = [[Daykundi]], [[Afghanistan]]http://www.meshran.website/pvd/showdoc.aspx?Id=14153 | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = [[Kabul, Afghanistan]] | nationality = {{AFG}} | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[American University of Afghanistan]]http://www.vitalvoices.org/node/1564 | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = [[10,000 Women|10,000 Women Entrepreneurial Achievement Award]] | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} {{Hazara people}} '''Fatema Akbari''' ({{lang-fa|فاطمه اکبری}}){{cite web|title=Fatema Akbari|publisher=[[Vital Voices|Vital Voices Global Partnership]]|url=http://www.vitalvoices.org/vital-voices-women/featured-voices/fatema-akbari|accessdate=14 September 2011}} is an [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] entrepreneur and women's advocate who is founder of the Gulistan Sadaqat Company and [[non-governmental organization]] the Women Affairs Council. In 2011 she received the [[10,000 Women]] Entrepreneurial Achievement Award.{{cite web |last=Reisner |first=Mimi |title=The Tenth Annual Vital Voices Global Leadership Awards |work=The Washington Scene |publisher=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=13 April 2011 |url=http://washingtonscene.thehill.com/party-events-pictures/archive/9143-the-tenth-annual-vital-voices-global-leadership-awards |accessdate=14 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110416222655/http://washingtonscene.thehill.com/party-events-pictures/archive/9143-the-tenth-annual-vital-voices-global-leadership-awards |archivedate=16 April 2011 |df= }} == Career == Fatema Akbari was driven into carpentry by necessity as a means of supporting her children following the death of her husband in 1999,{{cite web|title=Afghan women carve a career in a man’s world|publisher=[[NATO]]|date=8 March 2011|url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/news_71227.htm|accessdate=14 September 2011}} originally working on building sites in [[Iran]], where her family fled when the [[Taliban]] took control of Afghanistan. In 2003 she returned to homeland and started furniture manufacturing business by establishing '''Gulistan Sadaqat Company''' in [[Kabul]] with a carpentry school.{{cite web|last=Scott|first=Sylvia R.J.|title=Fatima Akbari, Afghan Mother, Role-Model, Social Entrepreneur and Business Owner|date=24 March 2011|url=http://sylviarjscott.com/women-entrepreneurs/fatima-akbari-afghan-mother-role-model-social-entrepreneur-and-business-owner/|accessdate=14 September 2011}} She attempted to provide a workforce base as a means of earning to wives of men killed or disabled during conflict in Afghanistan.{{cite web|title=Employee Dilemma: When Family and Business Don't Mix |work=Knowledge@Wharton |publisher=[[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] |date=6 January 2011 |url=http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/10000women/article.cfm?articleid=6230 |accessdate=14 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105221938/http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/10000women/article.cfm?articleid=6230 |archivedate=5 November 2011 |df= }} In 2009 she enrolled in the [[Goldman Sachs]]-sponsored [[10,000 Women]] program at the [[American University of Afghanistan]], a program aimed at training women from developing countries in business and management.{{Cite press release|url=http://www.10000women.org/PDFs/10000Women_PressRelease.pdf |title=Goldman Sachs Launces 10,000 Women |publisher=Goldman Sachs |date=5 March 2008 |accessdate=14 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gKbpAJOj?url=http://www.10000women.org/PDFs/10000Women_PressRelease.pdf |archivedate=2009-04-26 |deadurl=no |df= }} In expanding her operations and women's literacy classes, Akbari has been able to work in [[Taliban]]-controlled areas though negotiations with local leaders and has commented ''"It would be good for the Taliban to be involved in the country, to see that there’s nothing wrong with women leaving the house."''{{cite news|last=Kristof|first=Nicholas D.|title=What About Afghan Women?|newspaper=New York Times|location=New York City|date=23 October 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/24/opinion/24kristof.html|accessdate=14 September 2011}} In 2004, Fatema Akbari founded Afghanistan [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] the '''Women Affairs Council''' to train women in handicrafts in addition to educating both sexes about human rights.{{Cite conference|title=Building Afghanistan’s Future: Promoting Women’s Freedom and Advancing their Economic Opportunity |booktitle=Speakers and Panellists Bios |page=12 |publisher=[[George W. Bush Presidential Center#Policy Institute|George W. Bush Institute]] |date=March 31, 2011 |location=Dallas, Texas |url=http://www.bushcenter.com/images/downloads/TheInstitute/IntegratedInitiatives/WomensInitiatives/Speakers-and-Panelists.pdf |accessdate=14 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111218233209/http://bushcenter.com/images/downloads/TheInstitute/IntegratedInitiatives/WomensInitiatives/Speakers-and-Panelists.pdf |archivedate=18 December 2011 |df= }} Between the NGO and her own business, it was estimated that as of 2011 she had trained 5,610 people across Afghanistan. == 10,000 Women Entrepreneurial Achievement Award == On 12 April 2011 Akbari was honoured with the 10,000 Women Entrepreneurial Achievement Award at the [[Global Leadership Awards]]. In presenting, [[Vital Voices]] commended her
''"for her work to empower other Afghan women — through the training and employment provided by her carpentry business, and through the literacy and skills training provided by her non-governmental organization (NGO) to women in Taliban-controlled areas."''
== Further work == During 30–31 March 2011, Akbari was a panel member at a 2-day conference in [[Dallas, Texas]] convened by former United States President [[George W. Bush]] and Afghan President [[Hamid Karzai]] entitled ''Building Afghanistan’s Future: Promoting Women’s Freedom and Advancing Their Economic Opportunity''.{{Cite press release|title=Building Afghanistan's Future |publisher=[[George W. Bush Presidential Center#Policy Institute|George W. Bush Institute]] |date=March 31, 2011 |url=http://www.bushcenter.com/newsreleases/2011/03/building-afghanistans-future-promoting-womens-freedom-and-advancing-their-economic-opportunity |accessdate=14 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815235136/http://www.bushcenter.com/newsreleases/2011/03/building-afghanistans-future-promoting-womens-freedom-and-advancing-their-economic-opportunity |archivedate=15 August 2011 |df= }} == See also == {{Portal|Hazara people}} * [[List of Hazara people]] * [[10,000 Women]] * [[Vital Voices]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.vitalvoices.org/node/1564 Fatema Akbari @ Vital Voices] *[http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/10000women/category.cfm?catid=10 Fatema Akbari @ 10,000 Women] {{DEFAULTSORT:Akbari, Fatima}} [[Category:Afghan women in business]] [[Category:Hazara people]] [[Category:Afghan businesspeople]] [[Category:Hazara businesspeople]] [[Category:Afghan activists]] [[Category:Organisations based in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American University of Afghanistan]] [[Category:Women company founders]] [[Category:1974 births]]
